handbookguide-text: Smithing Plus – Smithing additions Smithing Plus implements various tweaks that enhance the vanilla smithing experience. The features are organized into distinct categories, and the configuration file allows you to enable or disable each category individually, as well as fine-tune each feature's behavior. Smith with bits Enables smithing with metal bits and native nuggets, including native copper, native silver, and native gold. If Geology Additions is installed, native platinum is also supported. To smith with bits, simply shift-click on an anvil—just as you would when using an ingot—while holding a hot metal bit. Like ingots in the base game, bits must be heated above their workable temperature (typically half of the melting point). To heat bits, warm them in a crucible placed over a firepit, and remove them before they begin to melt. Fuel with lower burning temperature such as firewood or peat is recommended. The configuration allows you to disable the use of bits for topping up existing smithing projects or for new projects independently. Tool recovery Tool recovery deviates significantly from vanilla behavior by allowing you to recover and repair broken metal tools. When a tool breaks—provided it has an associated smithing recipe or its crafting ingredients do, and it meets the configured selector—it will drop a broken tool head. This broken head acts as a work item that can be completed by smithing on an anvil. Smithing with bits pairs perfectly with this feature. There are many configuration options available, ranging from globally reducing the durability of repairable tools to managing the durability penalty incurred from multiple repairs. You can also configure which attributes to ignore, such as smithing quality from XSkills or enchantments from KRPG Enchantment, which by default will carry over to the repaired tool. Additionally, you can choose to make certain tool heads non-repairable; these can then be recycled into bits by using a chisel in the crafting grid. Bits recovery This category introduces the ability to recover bits when splitting material on an anvil. Due to the voxel-to-bit conversion being a fractional value, the number of voxels required to recover a bit can vary—typically two splits, but occasionally three. Additionally, it is possible to recover bits from a crucible containing solidified material. To do so, place the crucible and rightmouse-click on it while holding a chisel. Hammer Tweaks This category currently adds an alternative hammer tool-mode that enables you to flip smithing projects upside-down with a rightmouse-click. It can be configured to require tongs in the off-hand. Note: When this option is enabled, tongs will also be required to rotate the work item with a rightmouse-click. Casting Tweaks This category currently only introduces a configurable penalty to tools obtained through metal molding. The penalty is removed upon tool repair, as it is deemed proper smithing. Client Tweaks These adjustments are purely client-side quality-of-life improvements and include: • Additional handbook information for both smithing and metal molding • Display of necessary ingredient amount when selecting a smithing recipe • Visual presentation of current and total voxel counts when examining an anvil • Highlighting of workable temperature in the forge, anvil, and item tooltips, with a green indication when the item is at a workable temperature.
